comments.text: User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.8.0.4) Gecko/20060508 Firefox/1.5.0.4 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.8.0.4) Gecko/20060508 Firefox/1.5.0.4 I noticed this while attempting to create a page that used a list of links to browse to different sections of that same page (internal links or "bookmarks"). It's hard to explain without using examples, so I'll illustrate with code: Say I have a link - Bar An image below the link - And then a named anchor - I want the link to direct the browser to scroll down to the named anchor. What ends up happening is the browser is directed to the image instead. I assume that this will happen with any object in the page that shares the same name/id was the image. Whichever object the browser encounters first will be where the link is directed to. Please view the above URL to see the problem in action. Now, I was unable to find any information on standardization of object names and ids on the web, so perhaps it's just bad form for a designer to name two different objects the same thing. But testing this in other browsers, I was unable to replicate the problem. It may be that all the other browsers handle links to objects incorrectly and Firefox is the only one following standards, I don't know. I was always under the impression that an href could only point to a named anchor or another page, not a specific object within a page. Reproducible: Always Steps to Reproduce: 1. Create a page with a link, a named image, and an anchor of the same name 2. Click the link. 3. Boom!
comments.creator: chad@lemonhouseproductions.com

* id must be unique within the document
